title: Wall Street bonuses: asymmetric rewards set bankers up for griping
text:
Wall Street banks are splashing the cash. Record M&A activity and surging initial public offerings mean bankers are in line for outsized bonuses this year. But bumper payouts run the risk of alienating investors.

Goldman Sachs is considering increasing its bonus pool for its investment bankers by about 40-50 per cent compared with last year. At JPMorgan Chase, the increase could be as much as 40 per cent, the Financial Times reported.

Industry-wide, this year's expected bonus increases could be the biggest since 2009, according to compensation consultant Johnson Associates. Investment bankers and equities traders are set to receive the largest slices of the pie.

From a returns standpoint, that is justified — even though financing activity has been heavily underpinned by state support for the US economy amid pandemic challenges.

In the US, JPMorgan, Bank of America, Citigroup, Goldman Sachs and Morgan Stanley collectively took in more than $40bn in revenue from their investment banks during the first nine months of 2021. That is a 44 per cent surge from the prior-year period.

Yet the largesse could also set banks up in a potential tug of war with their investors. They grumble that bankers are well rewarded in good years but shielded in bad times.

Data from the Office of the New York State Comptroller show Wall Street losses almost quadrupled to $43bn during the Great Recession in 2008. Yet the bonus pool for that year shrank by only 47 per cent.

Still, investors have not done too poorly. The KBW Bank index has delivered a 35 per cent return this year. The biggest US banks have collectively announced plans to return billions of dollars to investors in the form of stock buybacks and dividends.

In a tight jobs market, banks need to retain talent but also keep a lid on costs. Loan growth is not expected to come roaring back next year. Trading and dealmaking could slow.

Bank bosses have a lot riding on their efficiency ratios, a measure of expenses to revenue. Bonus profligacy would derail the sector's strong run.
